title: Which one is grammatically correct, 'rise voices” or “raise voices'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Dictionaries are amazing! If you look in a dictionary and read the example sentences you will find not only the answer to your question, but you might learn something extra. The Oxford online dictionary, Lexico, gives plenty of example sentences that students can read to fully understand how native speakers use words. Some, if not most entries have over 15 example sentences! Raise | Definition of Raise by Oxford Dictionary on Lexico.com also meaning of Raise  Rise | Definition of Rise by Oxford Dictionary on Lexico.com also meaning of Rise  As you can see in the many example sentences and in the definition, for ‘rise’ there is ‘no object’. ‘Voices’ would be the object in any sentence you wanted to form with your example, so you need to use ‘raise’, which has objects in all the example sentences and the definition says ‘with object’. If you were a carpenter, would you go to work with a hammer? No? I didn’t think so. Apparently your job is to study language. Why aren’t you using your most important tool, a dictionary?

You and I “raise our voices.” When you and I raise our voices, our voices rise. (In other words, “raise” is the transitive verb - people raise something - and “rise” is the intransitive verb - something or someone rises.) Please note: In the US, a pay increase in pay is a “raise,” a noun. In the UK, an increase in pay may be called a “rise.” “Raise” is a regular verb. “Rise” is irregular: rise, rose, risen.
